prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not allowing my gf (28) to be friends with co-worker(of 3+ years) anymore for calling one of their co-workers her "boyfriend"?
A little background, me and my gf live together (3 Months now) but have been on and off for 4 years. She's been friends with this girl for 3+ years. My gf told me straight up that this guy (let's call him Sam from now on) Sam doesn't talk too anyone at their job (plenty of male female associates). But, since he has worked there he "waves" at my gf and is the only person at their job he kinda talks to. I was ok with that. I trusted her since she brought it up. 

I posted yesterday that we go through each other's phones. Well she deleted a few message. Most were innocent "what are you girls wearing tomorrow?". How I know you ask? Well she has a Fitbit and while she deletes her text on her phone her Fitbit takes longer to delete them. (this isn't the point of this post please don't focus or make your decision based off this). But I used the knowledge that she erased messages (she doesn't know her fitbit is betraying her) to let her tell me everything she deleted. Turns out that she deleted a message where her friend said something along the lines of "your boyfriend (Sam) was late to work last night" my gf told me that she ignored the message and moved the conversation on. I believe her because she is under the impression that I read it all (still thinks I hacked her phone when in reality she sank herself. I read one fitbit message).

After finding this out. I said "I don't want you to be friends with her anymore she doesn't respect me as your man and us as a couple". I know some people joke around and sometimes have innocent "work husband's". I'm not ok with either. I believe my gf should had told her friend that it's not ok to call another man that and I don't think her friend had a right to joke like that. 

Am I the asshole for not wanting her to keep that friend anymore? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for cutting off their girlfriend's friend because the friend called another coworker her "boyfriend." 

First, the situation: The girlfriend has been friends with this coworker (let's call her Sarah) for three years. The author is okay with the friend initially because he's told that the coworker (Sam) doesn't talk to many people, and he trusts his girlfriend. Then, the girlfriend deletes messages, and the author discovers through her Fitbit that she had a message where Sarah referred to Sam as her "boyfriend." The author confronts her, and now he wants her to stop being friends with Sarah because the friend doesn't respect him or their relationship.

Hmm. The key points here are the author's reaction and the reasons behind it. The author is upset because of the "boyfriend" comment. But is that a valid reason to end a three-year friendship? Also, the author is using the girlfriend's deleted messages as a way to confront her, which might be problematic. The girlfriend might have felt pressured to delete messages, which could indicate some control issues.

The friend called Sam "boyfriend," which could be a joke, as mentioned. The author is not okay with such terms, even if they're innocent. But cutting off a friend just because of a joke or a slip of the tongue might be overreacting. Also, the author's method of finding out (using Fitbit messages) is a bit sneaky, even if he didn't hack her phone. It shows a lack of trust and maybe an invasion of privacy.

The girlfriend might have had a valid reason to delete messages, maybe to avoid arguments or to protect her friend. But the author's response is to cut off the friend entirely. That seems harsh. The friend might not have intended to disrespect the author; it could have been a harmless joke. The author's reaction could be seen as controlling, especially since he's making a big decision without considering the context or the friend's intentions.

Additionally, the fact that the author is okay with the girlfriend deleting messages (she deleted other texts like "what are you wearing tomorrow?") suggests that there's some leniency in their relationship. But when it comes to the "boyfriend" comment, he's not okay with it. That inconsistency might also be an issue.

In relationships, communication is key. The author might have had the right to express his discomfort about the term, but cutting off the friend entirely without discussing it with his girlfriend or understanding the situation better could be seen as overstepping. The girlfriend might feel that her social life is being controlled, which could lead to further problems.

So, considering all that, the author's actions do seem like they're in the wrong. He's making a unilateral decision to end a long-term friendship based on a single comment, and his method of discovering the issue through sneaky means might undermine trust. The friend might not have intended disrespect, and the author's response is more about control than about the actual issue.
